content:
ry 28
												theHunter: Call of the Wild by Avalanche Studios, Expansive Worlds and astragon Entertainment might just be the “ground-breaking open world hunting simulator” you’ve been waiting for. The game implements realistic animal behavior, ballistics, and even weather cycles. There is not much of a tutorial and the player is dropped into the world with a gun and a map. Although there are initial voice overs and some tips, the player is pretty much left to their own devices.In regards to gameplay, the tracking mechanic can prove to be both frustrating and exciting. This is perhaps what lends it so well to creating an immersive experience that feels pretty real. While deer don’t have glowing prints, it is difficult not to feel excited when you realize you are getting close to one of the many types of wildlife in the game. It is also important to be on edge because many of the animals can turn and attack at a moment’s notice. It is hard not to feel excited when you finally line up that shot and pull the trigger. This game’s ballistics really alter the success of each shot based off of distance and trajectory so accuracy matters.However, I did find a few issues with the game. Due to the sheer size of the map and it being rendered all at once, the game is both beautiful and sometimes laggy. When prone I noticed that the grass does not connect to the ground, which caused clipping and obstruct the path at times. The most noteable glitch was a moose stuck in a hillside that would not die until it was shot five times. This is a big deal when ammo is limited and weapons are difficult to unlock in the beginning. There is also an auto walk feature, which is nice when walking great distances, but problematic when collecting trophies. This is because when doing so the game does not pause and you can walk off a cliff, be attacked by a bear, or both in my case.You can read the full review here {LINK REMOVED}http://bit.ly/GCypher7336

												Still crashes after 2 patches on a GTX 1080, 1440p G-Sync monitor.This could be a really good game but there's one issue which ruins it for mouse+keyboard users, the lack of being able to move slowly. If you want to move slowly without creating max noise then you'll need a joypad, even then it's not great as there's such a fine line between faster speed and no speed, you can adjust some joypad settings but no setting to actually adjust sensitivity for walking. It also feels dumbed down, sure you can make things harder by removing glow for the tracks but it still feels dumbed down, seems to be over populated with animals, there's also a stupid feature called "warning", basically the creature will hear you and make it's voice sound. Why on earth have such a stupid feature, it's like the developers have said ok how can we make the player find the various creatures easily, stupid. I mean a creature isn't going to shout out a warning if you're getting close because you made too much noise, stupid and dumbed down.The game looks really nice, much better than the 1st game and runs great at Ultra setting but does crash some sessions.You basically level up through xp, buy things, do missions. As for competitions, if you're expecting them to be like hunter classic, forget it. It's poorly implimented, noone bothers with them, they're not global.Multiplayer is pointless without well run competitions, noone bothers with them.If you've never played classic thehunter then you might like it, but for those that played the ortginal you'll be let down somewhat despite the great graphics.I'll continue to play it and hope they improve things soon but can't really reccomend it as a successor to TheHunter because it falls short in many ways.

Take collision with trees off at least?But other than that, the game is fineThere is not a whole lot more to a hunting game than what it already has guys. This isnt bass pro;s either, so they dont have an entire warehouse arsenal of hunting equipment for you to choose from. It's just the way it is and I can understand it.Overall 7.5/10, If the A.I is fixed 10/10

ry 27
												I had just spotted my first decent buck in Layton Lake and observed, attempting to get closer for a better shot. However, he quickly spooked and bolted off into the underbrush. I tracked him, but eventually gave up and decided to head for a nearby observation point and take in the scenery.I'd like to say, this game has perfectly captured how it feels to be in the woods. I hike occasionally during the summer and this is the first game I've ever seen that had me convinced my character was actually in a forest instead of just a clump of trees. The underbrush is great and the topogrophy is excellent. The way the lighting interacts with the trees and brush is absolutely perfect. Back to ingame, I continued along a path leading to the lookout tower. Then my attention was brought straight forward by the warning grunt of a black bear. I quickly dropped into a crouch and raised my rifle. Though some brush, I could see a bear with a cinnamon coat quartering towards me, coming along the path maybe 45 yards away. I lined up the reticle with the front of his shoulder, held my breath, pulled the trigger. He took a few more steps along the path, so I fired again, dropping him in his tracks.This is what you get when you purchase this product. A convincing virtual world and a rewarding experience. At times it's a painfully slow burner, but when you finally get that perfect shot you know that the game didn't give it to you. You earned it. P.S. to fans of turkey hunting, waterfowling and upland birds: They aren't currently included in the game but I have a strong suspicion they'll make their way in at some point.EDIT: I should mention there did seem to be a large infestation of bugs when the game was first released but it has been patched multiple times since release and I have yet to experience any game breaking bugs, just a few very minor graphical glitches.

ry 28
												TL:DR: Great game with loads of bugs, however not any gamebreaking ones I have found yet. However, before you buy try out the origiinal TheHunter for free, since the gameplay and concept are pretty much identical themselves,Pros:- Alot better graphics than the last thehunter. It makes the world feel much more immersive and gives sort of an ambient feeling when hunting. (which in my opinion makes it less boring)- NO MICROTRANSACTIONS! The previous hunter was a P2W game. If you are thinking of playing the previous thehunter because "oh oh oh, i dont want to buy this game but I still want to hunt for free bah baah blah" then you\re on the wrong track. You can unlock all species immideatly and can get better weapons by grinding them.- Night hunting. Nuff said.- This is by far the best (and one of the only) hunting game out there. Hunting simulation is a genre where currently, you do not have much choice.Cons:- Absolute garbage UI.- Multiplayer cons:   - Can't claim lookout points or outposts in multiplayer unless you are the owner of the server   - Server browser is absolute trash with very few filtering options   - Zones that appear that animals avoid when an animal is shot in the area do not match up with guests and the host   - Sometimes guests and owners see different animals (happens very rarely!)   - and loads of other small bugs- ALL OF THE BUGS! Seriously this and the UI is by far the biggest issue I have with this game. There are SO many of them and you will encounter them EVERYWHERE! They are not gamebreaking and do not exactly do that much, but this just feels like that the developers have not tested this game AT ALL or it's just a beta version (however, the game has already had a closed beta)- No trophy shots- No baiting barrelsSo, conclusion:If you want a hunting game, play the original TheHunter for a few hours and see if you like the waiting, the having to endlessly be careful not to sppok an animal and so on. If you do, buy this game! It's better than the original in almost every way (of course, except the bugs). It's a great game. There are none that compare to this. It's quite fun to play by yourself and even better if you play with your friends.

content:

												I picked up this game and started playing it on average computer. It was nice but I realized it was not running as it should. I was ready to give it up. Then I decided to buy a new gaming pc OMG this game comes to life on a good computer, gone is the slow hunter. I am the Ben Johnson of hunters!! This game is amazing in so many ways.if you are looking for easy go play something else. You have to treat this game like real life. Do you have a tutorial in real life?? I don't! You also won't start to enjoy the game until you get to around level 4. Have you ever been driving late at night and you are a little tired on a two lane highway? You know when your trying to stay awake and think ever bush is a deer or moose about to jump in front of you?? This  game does that!!  You swear that I'm the distance deer are bushes you squint your eyes trying to see but no that's just a bush not a deer!! Lol The people that say there are no animals? Just like real life the animals on this game are WILD!! Do you think they want to be shot and killed and eaten by me?? Heck no. They run and hide when they hear your noisy ♥♥♥ coming. They smell your old spice aftershave you splashed on this morning. Don't be stupid!! WILD animals are smarter than you!!You have to go slow, sure you can run to a place. But then your sure going to have to wait for things to calm down again after all the human noise you just made!!I myself have encountered very few problems with the game now that I'm running a 1070 video card and i7 processor. I'm on max setting on everything and it looks and feels like real life.The calls take a bit to get used to. Start with the small black one it travels further. The deer will come to you after awhile in the right location. When they get a little closer switch to the can call. I had one today come so close he was almost on top of me!!! Then I was so excited I missed from 5feet  away lol . Just remember if you kill something move on because that area is full of the animals dead smell now lol great feature, it makes you move on and explore more.This is bar none the best and most realist hunting game out there by far!!  I have much more to unlock and I am super happy with how it's going so far. I can't wait to see what else is in here!Great game with so many options on what you can do. Walk around or just find a place to bring them in. Buy this if you have the computer to run it! And they taste great too!!

content:
ry 19
												First Steam review so bear with me...The Basics: A hunting "simulator" that drops you into a massive map with a gun in your hand a somewhat helpful voice in your ear. No real setup, just cuts you loose with some very basic and in my opinion decent enough tutorial messages. You could follow the missions that pop up on your huntermate or ignore them. As far as I can tell, nothing is gated behind the completion of any of them. So as soon as you start you can do as you please, unlock outposts, lookout points and other assorted collectibles around the land. Not to mention trying to land your first, of many, kills.Graphics: Game is gorgeous as hell. Dense forests that give way to open fields, lakes and rivers carving through the hills. Its just a treat to look at. Not to mention the animals are very well done also. Though if I'm honest (and that's the point right?) the animals could maybe use a second albeit small touch up. Nothing a non critical eye would notice. I can't help but feel like this is the way game maps were supposed to be designed from the beginning. It's so great walking through the bushes and branches hoping that you can get a shot on a deer you can barely makeout in the distance. There are a few low texture and blurry bits but I was too awestruck to notice until the five hour mark. Sound: The sounds are great and not great. Mixed bag. Mainly some are too loud. Some are recycled leading to confusion and some are kind of odd. The rain is an example of excellence. I absolutely love the rain in this game. It truly feels like I am standing in the forest in a storm, and when thunder occurs, I nearly jumped from my seat. Example of bad sound is when for instance, a rabbit takes off from a few feet from you. Not only is it loud as balls, but it makes the same sound as your polyester jacket scraping tree branches. Sounds like this being repeated led to me constantly wondering if a deer responded to my calls, a rabbit got startled, or I'm just molesting a tree. Another positive though, the voiceovers are quite nice. (at least so far)Gameplay: It's an incredibly simple premise done quite well. You go into the forest and shoot animals. Main drive is to bag the biggest and best you can. It's a very addictive cycle for myself. The game makes it very easy to decide whats worth you ammo. You get experience for better kills ie right tool for the animal, quick kills, and better trophies. You also level up your skill with a particular weapon or tool type which opens up new variants at an oupost. There are perks and skills that allow you to alleviate the difficulty in subtle and so far non game breaking ways.ETC: The main gripe here with most people is the grind. It takes a long time to begin unlocking things. Me personally though, the gun you start with is more than sufficient and games like these aren't about racing to the end, it's the journey along the way. Other issues are that when playing with a keyboard and mouse it's currently impossible to sneak effectively. No matter the stance you make hella noise moving through any kind of underbrush. And yes, there are reports of quite a few assorted bugs. Missing ammo, scopes not working, animals glitching out. I haven't personally experienced these but I feel for those who are. I trust that given a little bit of time, the dev team will iron these things out and build upon the solid foundation that they have laid. Even the early days of the Hunter classic were an ugly time.  TLDR: Buggy, beautiful, and fun as hell. When it comes down to it, this game at its worst is miles better than any other hunting game at it's best.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 16
												This is for anyone who has yet to purchase TheHunter: Call of the Wild.So far I have clocked in over 10 hours + playing TheHunter and from what I have seen so far the game has a lot of good, bad, and broken in it.Bad points:-The menu doesn’t work half the time, doing something as simple as switching weapons can take me 10-15 min’s just trying to get it to work sometimes.-Frame rate drops from time to time.(I have a higher end PC)-Animals get stuck all the time, in my 10+ hours it has happened more than a few times.One time I wiped out an entire herd, just walked up to them and popped them all one at a time.-Can fall quite a distance with taking minimal damage, but fall a few inches next to a rock and you die?-The sound the game makes when you brush up against… brush doesn’t sound right to me. When I walk through brush I turn around time after time because it sounds like it's off in the distance and not me making the noise. Might just be me though but drove me nuts!-The most success I had hunting was running through the forest, not sneaking. It is still way more realistic than other hunting games, but I shouldn’t be able to jog up a road and drop 5 animals.-Do not try to switch keybindings or you might get stuck for a bit. If you already messed with the shoot button just scroll down to the bottom and reset everything and don’t touch it until patches fix that monstrosity.-Few crashes throughout the day.-Sound sometimes cuts in and out, usually when it’s raining.-Camo does nothing...The GOOD!-Graphics Look AMAZING, game does need to be optimized a bit though.-It feels like a new game but does keep a lot of the core components of the original game, If you played TheHunter Classic you will feel at home with this game.-MASSIVE BEAUTIFUL world.-I am satisfied every time I pull the trigger, and the animal animations are awesome.(when they aren’t stuck running in place from a rock,tree, or one foot hill) The game has a lot wrong with it right now, I have no doubt that the game was rushed out. A lot of the problems seem like they could be quick fixes, but these problems should have NOT been in the release. And testing for more than an hour or two would have pinpointed the problems easily. But with all of that the game is still great, I have enjoyed spending the whole day on the game and haven’t felt bored. So for a new buyer I would have to say hold off until they fix a few of the bugs. The game is not unplayable by any means but I feel like some standards need to be held, especially for a $30 game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
5
												I really want to like this game, I sent the devs an email and they reassured me that the game will get its patches. I can definetly see why people would be concerned about their commitment, the game is still in its extremely early stages and should be marked as so. This game has a ton of work that needs to be done. I will name off some of the things that bother me.  1st thing that makes me frustrated is how weak the weapons are, a Headshot with a 12 gauge shot is not enough for a deer apperantly. After still dumping another 4 slugs into it, the deer managed to survive with it only having a blood rate of low. Same thing goes for the bow. While I understand that their is a point to chase them down and finishing the job but having to do that everytime with any weapon but the rifle is a little excessive.  Next thing on my list is having to walk everywhere. you can only fast travel to the one campground so I try to avoid the missions because the map is so huge. While I understand that you should explore the map, it really bugs me having to fast travel to the one camp on the map after a mission to rest until sundown then have to do a 15 minute walk back to the same area from your last mission to hunt the same animals at night.  My final issue with the game is the prices of the items, while they lowered the cost of the actual firearms on the latest patch they raised the price of ammo making it ridiculous to actually get far. Once you purchase a weapon you barely are left with any money to buy ammo. It wouldnt be so bad but when animals only garnish ~$600 and you dump 5 out of 8 slugs into it you end not being able to afford it because you only get 8 slugs for $980.The good things about the game are the graphics, the sounds, and the generally calming expirience of hunting. The AI is pretty decent when they dont run around in circles or get stuck between the rocks.  Tracking deer is an exciting experience with the help of the phone, when its not killing your fps it really helps out. Not a ton to hunt from yet, the deer seem to be more aggressive than a black bear when shot. Not sure if thats %100 accurate. Also something to note, this game requires patience. Unfortunately you cant run up to any deer and shoot them willy nilly. You actually have crouch and crawl to get close, if they dont pick up your scent from the gust of wind. Weapon selection is decent, they start you from a rifle and after a couple kills you can afford handguns, shotguns and, bows. From there you can customize them by adding a sight or getting better ammo. If you do get the bow I recommend restarting your game if want you use your rifle with a scope, bugs out and doesnt work right.All in all its a great game but there is a ton and i mean a TON of work that needs to be done before this is even considered an actual game. At the moment as I write this review I do not reccomend this to anyone yet. Wait until a couple good solid patches are released. Until then my review will stay the same status unless they adjust it to an early access title. I believe that this game has a lot of potential and can easily be the greatest hunting game ever but the devs have a lot of work on their hands. TL;DR Don't buy yet.

I've found that using a combination of keyboard/mouse for the interfaces and a controller for normal gameplay to be the best, but there are improvements that could be made on both sides. The interfaces do not work well with the controller, but the controller does provide the advantage of taking a slow approach when stalking.

												This game has met all my expectations and a little more even, yea it has bugs but the devs are working on fixes around the clock. first ill start off with the pros.PROS- Sound quality is extremly detailed and some of the best ive heard in any outdoor/hunting game (sounds just like real life imo)- The graphics are really good compared to classic- The environments and animals are incredibly detailed and super realistic- Animations look as life like as if you were actually watching a real deer- AI is decent although it could be better (for example the animals call way to often and ocasionally walk into trees and get stuck)- The missions are fun and keep you wanting to play more of them- The reserves are absolutely massive and it would definitly take a long time to have explored every inch of hunting area- One time purchase with no micro transactions whatsoever (A big improvement over TheHunter classic)- Leveling seems balanced although if you dont play some of the missions it will take significantly longer to progress- the animals act in the ways they would in real life (for example the elk are found commonly in herds of 15+ and stick together when traveling, the animals react to getting shot very realisticly too)CONS-The frame rate is a little low compared to what my pc should be getting ( i have a gtx 970, 3.5ghz 8 core processor, 16gb ram, 750 watt power supply and i get 50-80 fps on high)- It takes way too long to unlock new guns/equipment ( ive played 16 hours since release and ive only unlocked 1 new rifle after 80+ kills)-Their isnt as much veriety in antler variation as i would like (compared to classic atleast)- Its too easy to find large trophys, it should be more difficult to find the bigger trophys and smaller ones should be more common but instead its the other way around in this game- There are quite a bit of bugs as of now but they are putting out patches every day so its not a huge problemOver all i really have enjoyed the game and i would definitly recommend it to anyone who likes hunting or just wants a beautiful looking game to play. Sure its not perfect but its definitly worth the 29.99 and the devs are working hard on improving the game and are actually listening to the feedback they are getting. Cant wait to see what the future hold for this game!!!

												Update: It's now been revealed this is in fact a console port, an unfinished buggy console port sold at full price in a beta condition.This is the worst gaming experience I have had in over 20 years of gaming and this is the first game I have deleted permanently from my steam accounts, I am done with this game.Kudos to those who allow themselves to be treated this way, I am not one of them.The forums are run by fanboys who delete and ban people for the slightest criticism of their precious little game, I was unaware people this weak minded existed.So go ♥♥♥♥ yourself AlfTupper, should our paths ever cross in real life the outcome will be very very different of that I can assure you.It beggars belief how this game was released as "game ready", little has been fixed with the patching to date and the unfinished state of this game is apparent every time you try and play, each patch brings with it new bugs to add to the ever growing Big Bug Report Thread, If you're happy to spend £30 to join a Beta program then buy it.This game delivers graphically but is left wanting in all other departments, I suggest you read the current bugs/unfinished features list before buying.http://steamcommunity.com/app/518790/discussions/5/133258092257803156/Flawed AI, stuck animals, disappearing animals, broken caller animations, broken animal animations, missing animal animations, broken tracking, the sound balance and positioning is crude and undeveloped, The UI is an abomination of design and navigation etc, the list is endless and each subsequent patch brings more and more bugs to the game.Deathly silence in the forums from the Devs other than a few token "marketing" style posts, they are happy to sit back and watch the forum fall apart whilst spending most of their time on the review section posting "damage limitation" responses to negative reviews. 1000's of questions are asked but not a single one is addressed by the devs, the "community" is left to argue amongst itself.The forum moderators are hand picked from the original beta testing team so it's pretty clear where their loyalties lie, the forums are bias to the extreme, anyone criticising the game or it's developers are jumped on by the die hard fan base with calls of "cryer" "whiner" or "your computers a potato" resulting in flaming and threads being (conveniently) locked and posts being (conveniently) deleted.I can't for one second recommend anybody purchase this game in it's current state, yes the game looks good, yes it draws you in and immerses you into the environment, then it proceeds to slowly reveal flaw upon immersion breaking flaw to ruin the experience, If your gaming requirements are slightly above average you are in for a frustrating experience, if you like to run around a pretty environment oblivious of the bugs, shooting anything that moves, "high fiving" every kill and taking screenshots you will love it.Until I see active participation in the forums by the devs, I'm considering it a waste of time and energy suggestion improvements, these guys have their roadmap and everybody else is well and truly on it, just like their previous titles, do your research on Avalanche Studios and Expansive Worlds, put the hype aside and take a look at their track record with theHunter Classic, and Primal, these guys have a history of not finishing things.It's too early to give a detailed review because the game isn't yet "game ready".

												habe das game jetzt ca. 4 stunden gespielt. nur im Multiplayer mit Freunden... leider musste ich feststellen das der Multiplayer nur für den Host "attraktiv" ist. Denn es ist nur dem Host möglich, die einzelnen Map-Punkte (u.a. "Aussenposten" "interessante Orte" und "Aussichtspunkte") zu erkunden. Die anderen Mitspieler können lediglich Jagen und dafür Punkte bekommen. Apro pos Punkte: Diese werden auch nur dann verteilt wenn man auf ein Tier geschossen hat, wenn dem nicht so ist, bekommt man rein gar nichts....Fazit:-) Multiplayer sollte ausgereift werden - alle Mitspieler sollten Waypoint aktivieren können.-) Gemeinsames Jagen sollte verbessert werden - Belohnungen beim Jagen sollten alle erhaltne, nicht nur wenn man draufgeschossen hat.-) Falldamage anpassen, da nicht realistisch. Man kann von einem Aussichtspunkt hinunter springen und man erleidet einen sehr geringen Schaden! Beim Springen auf eine Holzbank ist man tot. usw.-) Zielfernrohr ist manchmal verbuggt - das zoomen bei der Waffe funktioniert nicht korrekt, man sieht durch das Zielfernrorh und sieht dabei seine Hände und das Rohr ist extrem klein!-) Menü funktioniert nicht korrekt: Eine Auswahl ist manchmal nicht möglich, man muss 2-3 mal klicken.-) Muitionskauf: Man kann diese zwar kaufen, aber man sieht nicht wieviel Munition man gekauft hat. Nur wenn man aus dem Menü raus geht und die Waffe auswählt. Im "Lager" wird die Munition ebenfalls irgendwann angezeigt...-) Kein Zurück zum Haupt-Menü: Man muss andauernd das Spiel beenden und neustarten.-) usw. - ich hoffe die Entwickler sehen diesen Beitrag und werden diese Bugs ausbessern.... leider ist es mir nicht mehr möglich das Spiel zurückzugeben, sonst würde ich das auch machen!Für mich ist es eine Alpha-Versiojn und überhaupt nicht ausgereift! - Unbedingt Updates notwendig! - Keine Kaufempfehlung!

												The slow pace of hunting, the minimalistic UI, the sounds, and gorgeous graphics makes theHunter an impressively immersive experience that manages to be pretty relaxing and thrilling at the same time. The gameplay is in my short experience pretty simplistic, which is probably a necessity given that it's a pretty unique game. You find a trace, you follow it, you shoot the animal, everybody happy. It certainly has depth though, and the world feels very alive, despite pretty much just being you, the land, and the animals. I would attribute this to the AI of the animals combined with the mechanics of the world more than anything, as they'll pretty realistically react to noises, sightings, et cetera.My main gripes with the game seem to be things that will hopefully be improved upon in later patches. Namely, the tutorial is more or less just text boxes popping up every once in a while. Even though learning through playing might work, there's a good few mechanics that just aren't explained all that well and given how this isn't a common/mainstream type of game, a proper tutorial would really make it easier to get into the game.Secondly there's a slight lack of polish in some areas. Menus are a bit clunky and there are some smaller graphical bugs. The positional audio could use some work too, it would be an amazing asset to the immersion but there's just something off about it in terms of volume levels and direction.

												theHunter Call of The Wild is a great game. It's beautiful and has a lot to offer. Hunting seems to be much more improved in this game than the previous hunter and it's nice that you don't have to pay monthly to hunt where you want and what you want. Although it's very hard to ignore the obvious bugs in the game. Sometimes your game will crash, FPS drops aren't common but they happen, your mission progress will get stuck and force you to restart your save, scope glitches when you fire making it difficult to track a animal after you shot, animals will sometimes get stuck, and tracks can completetly disappear forcing you to restart the game. The game is a lot of fun and has a lot of potential. Most definitetly a step up from the previous game. Much more improved mechhanics and several new weapons as well. If you're able to withstand the crashes and bugs this game has then I would definitetly say buy it especially if you're a fan of the previous game. When the game works as intended it's a blast to play and I don't regret buying it at all. Hopefully the devs keep to this game and don't abandon it like they did with theHunter Primal.

content:
ry 23
												TLDR:The game is playable and enjoyable but riddled with bugs so much so you might mistake this game for an early access rather than an actual game release. The gameplay itself is simple but even then the AI of the animals is lacking in so many ways with pathfinding issues. I'd say that in my 300 "harvests" of animals that around 1/3 of those were from "bugged animals" which were either standing still, running in place or stuck on the terrain. I didnt buy a hunting game only to be shooting fish in a barrel.Running the game on Max settings GTX 1080 i7-6500 3.4Ghz 16gig RAM rig runs the game perfectly, suffer from random audio crashes that have yet to be fixed despite many people suffering from it.Single player missions are a joke, often asking you to take a picture of a deer but the quest itself is bugged and no amount of pictures or the distance you are to the deer will make a difference. With the latest patch the developers essentially ripped away whatever progression system the game has, the idea is that you hunt animals and gain EXP, weapon experience and money. The developers have made it possible to essentially have end game gear within hours of playing by drastically reducing the amouint of experience needed to unlock these weapons (seriously i'd say they reduced the amount needed by about 80%). So now i have the end game weapons and can kill animals easily from an enormous distance so now what? I could go ahead and try and hunt the biggest trophies in the game for the bragging rights on the global leaderboards like in theHunter classic? WRONG. There is a leaderboards amongst your friend list but thats it and even then it isnt even working right now and doesnt update itself often.The game is nothing like a hunting game, if you think you are going to be sneaking up on groups of animals, picking out the biggest trophy and taking it down then think again! The game as it is punishes players who just hunt for trophies as far as progression is concerned. It's actually more beneficial for to kill every animal you see no matter what size or gender than going for a trophy, the difference in rewards between a trophy and a crappy female deer is tiny, maybe a third less money and EXP, the game doesnt even punish you for killing an animal with the wrong weapon nor does it punish you for failing to track a wounded animal down and finishing it off. so it gets to a point where you just shoot an animal and if you find that its barely wounded your better off just leaving it and finding some other animal to shoot at.If the developers want this game to last longer than a few months then they really need to make some major changes to this game, which is a shame because it could be a very good game once they fixed all the bugs and actually made it feel like you were hunting rather than playing some arcade shoot em up with deers instead of zombies.WIll change this review once game becomes more playable but if anyone is reading this right now please save your money for now, watch this game and keep an eye on its updates and maybe even catch it in a steam sale a few months down the line.

												Hello everyone! I really hope this review can help you wether buy the game or not, so lets get into it.theHunter: Call of the Wild has the potential to become the best and bigger hunting game in the market so far...I've been playing it for a while and I'm not dissapointed for the price.HOWEVER, there are still many small and medium bugs that need to be fixed in order to give the customer a proper game experience.How is that? I will explain it now.Some little bugs like sound glitches such as choppy rain effect when you are anywhere near a lake or river (10 meters or so) or the scope dissapearing for half a second when you shoot (only 2 out of 10 shots)The bugs that I'm more worried about is that the game GUI is completely unfriendly. I mean, I cannot change the mouse sensitivity since the mouse/keyboard does NOT have an "Apply" button, and when it comes to the loadout it's a little bit confusing or even sometimes the mouse click does not work anymore, so you have to close the thing and re-open it.Sometimes the animals will get stuck and will be an easy prey for you, or even dissapear (2 out of the 30 deers I've hunted so far had completely dissapeared, meaning that the tracks are entirely gone after a few miles of tracking, and it is kind of annoying)You will also have to invest many hours playing it, so if you are a busy person I recommend playing something less time demanding, since the game itself it is ment to be played slowly, no runnin n' gunnin' here mates.Now it has plenty of good things aswell...the atmosphere of the game its outstanding, the graphic its astounding, the lightning its well made, and the places are huges and not repetitive. You've got a story mode that kind of reminds me to "Firewatch", the voice acting it's really good, and if you are looking for a game to relax, give it a shot, it has been worth my time.Overall the game its pretty playable, and me being some kind of "lone ranger", I've enjoyed my time with it...I will come back later to make an update and answer questions of the people who are intending to buy it.Many thanks for reading and don't be afraid to ask.Peace!

												I'm only about two hours into the game, but initial impressions are very positive.  The Good:Graphics are lovely, foliage density, lighting, weather--it's all on point.  I have brought my binoculars up multiple times checking if that movement in the distance is an animal, only to find a blowing branch or moving shadows. This really added to the immersiveness for me.  Branches and grass bend as you stalk past.  Playing the game with maxed settings (albeit at 1080p) with a constant 65fps, optimization seems solid, CPU/GPU temps both stayed well within reason.  intel i5 3.4GHz / gtx 980Sound is on point as well, highly directional, underbrush crunches, animals chirp, hoot, hollar and otherwise immerse you in the living environment.Core gameplay is solid.  Tracking, stalking, and shooting make for a fun formula.  I like that the hunting help (glowing tracks, directional assistance) are customizable, letting you play at the level of attention-to-detail you desire.  There seem to be plenty of progression options: weapon choices, different scopes, lures, binoculars; as well as a leveling skill/perk system.  And yet, the starting rifle feels plenty suitable for the game i've encountered thus far, so I don't feel rushed to level or worry about that stuff yet.The Bad:As some of the other reviews mentioned, the menu controls are kinda strange at times.  Either they occasionally hang so that you can't back out entirely, or there is some element of the selection that is somewhat tricky/unclear.  It hasn't caused me any major setbacks as a combination of escape and selecting the settings menu has allowed me to resume each time.  There don't seem to be many 'visual' character customization options.  Character presets  are pretty limited as are outfits.  This doesn't matter to me right now, but may become more important when I try out the multiplayer gameplay options.The To Be Continued:Haven't tried the multiplayer.  As that is the primary reason I was anticipating this game, I will have to update once I've had a chance to do so.

												Here is my opinion, after the first 10+ hours of the game.There should be no doubt that this game has great potential but currently lacks due to some bugs. Unfortunately, it's not something smallish and not so important stuff. Let me give an example. I have during my first few hours in the game already encountered numerous bugs where the animals are stuck in trees and rocks and keep running like they were on ecstacy, it might be fun to look at but after some time, you just get really annoyed about it. They might be easy to shoot - but they kill the overall feeling about being on a "real hunt". Another major flaw is the lack of greater depth in the multiplayer session. If you or your partner is the host of the server you play on, then it would be impossible for the other part to get certain spots on the map. Which again, unfortunately, sucks big time because of the distance between areas and places like "save zone/fast travel". They really need some kind of vehicle to reduce the distance to certain areas like this. Otherwise i think a lot of people would get tired of just walking/running from the other end of the map to another. Also I would like to see some more challenges online, not just those few they have right now, but something which could be a lot more interesting to do. Graphic wise, I think it look's really good. And the sounds are not bad at all. Small adjustments here and there would make this part of the game to be some of the best with The Hunter: Call of the Wild. Is it worth buying now? It depends on whether you are willing to invest in a product that possibly should have waited 2-3 months longer to correct some crucial bugs as the game crashes from time to time. (Something the dev's are working on right now). Even though this review seems negative, I just can't get myself to press the "negative" button. I think if some of those things i have written is going to change, then this game can get really good over time! At least im exicited to see what the future brings, hopefully more animals, new areas, easier level system, and vehicles.

Graphics are amazing, lots of details with the grass, water, and other things. Sounds are pretty on point and the timing of where you are and the noise level are pretty amazing. Optimizing needs some work. I have an ok gaming pc, for example I can play Gta 5 online on high settings and do about 60 - 80 fps. This game I can only run on low settings and get about 20 - 35 fps. Animals do get stuck sometimes like on rocks on the side of a hill which gives the player a huge chance at getting the animals. The good news is all the downsides are pretty simple changes if they decide to do them. Another con is that when you shoot the weapon with the scope on, it will glitch out and you will have to re-aim which means if you got a bad shot on the animal then your probly gonna be tracking it for a while unless your fast and re-aiming and shooting the target. I still recommend the game because the experience is like no other game out there. Animal movements are pretty realistic and cool to see in a game. For $30 I recommend this game and this game just released, so many changes are going to happen. Keep that in mind!

content:
ry 17
tl;dr – if you like huntin' and/or huntin' games...buy it!!You know what? So far, I like this game! It seems to be the start of the hunting game I've always wanted. I've over the years played a few, and I liked "theHunter: Classic" too. However, I always felt that "theHunter: Classic" was too bloated & bogged down with micro-transactions to get any real enjoyment out of it. This one though, I think has a ton of potential and I'm looking forward to what "Expansive Worlds" has in store for it. As far as all the hate and negativity – I'm not sure why, nor do I care to debate it. I may be in a minority, but I've had no issues with the game whats-so-ever. I say that, though, having started playing it after the patches began rolling out. So maybe it was pretty bad during the launch, I don’t know. I just know I can currently run the game on one GTX 1080, with maxed out in-game settings, at around 50-75fps. Graphics wise – (to me & my "seasoned" eyes) the game looks pretty nice. Wonderful scenery and grand vistas abound – both of which, I feel, can be pretty awe inspiring. When looking at the world around you, from both ground level and from an observation tower; you get a sense of how big the world you’re in really is. Sound wise – the voice acting, the music, and sound effects has been done pretty well. The detailed sounds of the animal living life & their movements about, along with the enviromental effects such as; the rain, wind, cracking branches, and the crunch of the ground under foot all add to the sense of immersion and brings to life the feeling of truly being in the woods stalking / hunting my prey. While the game is nice, it’s not perfect. A few complaints worth mentioning are: (1) Optimization could be a little better, and on the graphics front – I would like to see SLI support added. (2) Scene coloring, as well as the overall “crispness” of the textures could be better – perhaps a few in-game adjustment sliders could help with this? (3) UI wonkiness...like not being able to exit the settings menu without going to the map?? (4) Game pad support, even keyboard control binding could definitely be improved upon. The lag between trying to rebind a key, and the time the game accepts is pretty strange. Usually you have no idea if you’re currently rebinding or not, because we are given no confirmation and/or feedback from this system. Controller wise, I was unable to you the controller exclusively without using the keyboard to bail me out…I’m looking at you menus! For most this won’t be an issue, as many will probably not dare use a controller, but some of us (with semi-worn out joints) find comfort in using the gamepad from time to time.This game and others like it won't be for everyone. Overall though, I would, and do recommend this game for purchase! However if you're not a fan of the genre, but find yourself curious – I would suggest a "buy & try" during a sale sometime. That being said...Happy Hunting!!

This one though, I think has a ton of potential and I'm looking forward to what "Expansive Worlds" has in store for it. As far as all the hate and negativity – I'm not sure why, nor do I care to debate it. I may be in a minority, but I've had no issues with the game whats-so-ever. I say that, though, having started playing it after the patches began rolling out. So maybe it was pretty bad during the launch, I don’t know. I just know I can currently run the game on one GTX 1080, with maxed out in-game settings, at around 50-75fps. Graphics wise – (to me & my "seasoned" eyes) the game looks pretty nice. Wonderful scenery and grand vistas abound – both of which, I feel, can be pretty awe inspiring. When looking at the world around you, from both ground level and from an observation tower; you get a sense of how big the world you’re in really is. Sound wise – the voice acting, the music, and sound effects has been done pretty well. The detailed sounds of the animal living life & their movements about, along with the enviromental effects such as; the rain, wind, cracking branches, and the crunch of the ground under foot all add to the sense of immersion and brings to life the feeling of truly being in the woods stalking / hunting my prey. While the game is nice, it’s not perfect. A few complaints worth mentioning are: (1) Optimization could be a little better, and on the graphics front – I would like to see SLI support added. (2) Scene coloring, as well as the overall “crispness” of the textures could be better – perhaps a few in-game adjustment sliders could help with this? (3) UI wonkiness...like not being able to exit the settings menu without going to the map?? (4) Game pad support, even keyboard control binding could definitely be improved upon. The lag between trying to rebind a key, and the time the game accepts is pretty strange. Usually you have no idea if you’re currently rebinding or not, because we are given no confirmation and/or feedback from this system. Controller wise, I was unable to you the controller exclusively without using the keyboard to bail me out…I’m looking at you menus! For most this won’t be an issue, as many will probably not dare use a controller, but some of us (with semi-worn out joints) find comfort in using the gamepad from time to time.This game and others like it won't be for everyone. Overall though, I would, and do recommend this game for purchase! However if you're not a fan of the genre, but find yourself curious – I would suggest a "buy & try" during a sale sometime. That being said...Happy Hunting!!

content:

												I'm only about two hours into the game, but initial impressions are very positive.  The Good:Graphics are lovely, foliage density, lighting, weather--it's all on point.  I have brought my binoculars up multiple times checking if that movement in the distance is an animal, only to find a blowing branch or moving shadows. This really added to the immersiveness for me.  Branches and grass bend as you stalk past.  Playing the game with maxed settings (albeit at 1080p) with a constant 65fps, optimization seems solid, CPU/GPU temps both stayed well within reason.  intel i5 3.4GHz / gtx 980Sound is on point as well, highly directional, underbrush crunches, animals chirp, hoot, hollar and otherwise immerse you in the living environment.Core gameplay is solid.  Tracking, stalking, and shooting make for a fun formula.  I like that the hunting help (glowing tracks, directional assistance) are customizable, letting you play at the level of attention-to-detail you desire.  There seem to be plenty of progression options: weapon choices, different scopes, lures, binoculars; as well as a leveling skill/perk system.  And yet, the starting rifle feels plenty suitable for the game i've encountered thus far, so I don't feel rushed to level or worry about that stuff yet.The Bad:As some of the other reviews mentioned, the menu controls are kinda strange at times.  Either they occasionally hang so that you can't back out entirely, or there is some element of the selection that is somewhat tricky/unclear.  It hasn't caused me any major setbacks as a combination of escape and selecting the settings menu has allowed me to resume each time.  There don't seem to be many 'visual' character customization options.  Character presets  are pretty limited as are outfits.  This doesn't matter to me right now, but may become more important when I try out the multiplayer gameplay options.The To Be Continued:Haven't tried the multiplayer.  As that is the primary reason I was anticipating this game, I will have to update once I've had a chance to do so.

												Here is my opinion, after the first 10+ hours of the game.There should be no doubt that this game has great potential but currently lacks due to some bugs. Unfortunately, it's not something smallish and not so important stuff. Let me give an example. I have during my first few hours in the game already encountered numerous bugs where the animals are stuck in trees and rocks and keep running like they were on ecstacy, it might be fun to look at but after some time, you just get really annoyed about it. They might be easy to shoot - but they kill the overall feeling about being on a "real hunt". Another major flaw is the lack of greater depth in the multiplayer session. If you or your partner is the host of the server you play on, then it would be impossible for the other part to get certain spots on the map. Which again, unfortunately, sucks big time because of the distance between areas and places like "save zone/fast travel". They really need some kind of vehicle to reduce the distance to certain areas like this. Otherwise i think a lot of people would get tired of just walking/running from the other end of the map to another. Also I would like to see some more challenges online, not just those few they have right now, but something which could be a lot more interesting to do. Graphic wise, I think it look's really good. And the sounds are not bad at all. Small adjustments here and there would make this part of the game to be some of the best with The Hunter: Call of the Wild. Is it worth buying now? It depends on whether you are willing to invest in a product that possibly should have waited 2-3 months longer to correct some crucial bugs as the game crashes from time to time. (Something the dev's are working on right now). Even though this review seems negative, I just can't get myself to press the "negative" button. I think if some of those things i have written is going to change, then this game can get really good over time! At least im exicited to see what the future brings, hopefully more animals, new areas, easier level system, and vehicles.

												I just wanted to write this quick review - I'm a slightly older gamer than average I guess, so tend not to buy new Games the moment they appear (i.e. I'm a skinflint and remember when Games were £5 new!)...anyway was convinced to buy this as I do a bit of hunting in real life.And WOW am I impressed - stunning graphics ( I play at 4k on a 55inch OLED and it's Fricking beautiful!)Gameplay is good,Animal AI seem pretty good, I've not seen ANY of the many bugs that people have reported from earlier versions.Weapons handling seems very realistic - two small improvements could be the ability to rest the weapon, i.e. stabilise it on a Tree or Rock or whatever with a bipod etc... And the fatigue that should set in for holding a weapon on aim over time... But apart from that, spot on.I've literally spent the last weekend "Away on a Hunting trip" and am embarressed to admit I cancelled a REAL shooting morning with my buddies on Sunday to play this.... sad eh !?Anyway if you're slightly interested in sneaking around in the bushes and a game that has a slower more organic pace, then I would recommend this one to you..Worth every penny !SJ

												This game certainly has some strong qualities. Great graphics. Excellent lighting effects, weather effects etc.Really large map. Nice weapons and accessories.Tracking system is not overcomplicated.But it also has some weak qualities. No vehicles on a ridiculously large map. You have to walk everywhere. All of the time. It's so boring sometimes when you just want to go from point A to point B.The level progression is insanely slow, to the point where it can take days to get a new weapon. No way to pause the game, literally, none. You can't rest without paying the money you earned from hunting. That's the dumbest thing I've ever seen in a video game. In the current state I do not recommend this game. It is good for just relaxing instead of going fast paced like in most games, but other than that it needs some serious improvements in those areas.EDIT: Still giving it a go. I just went up a tower to survey the land, with the intent on finding the nearest hunting camp afterwards. Fell off the tower, now I have to walk nearly 2KM to get to the new camp. All because there are nowhere near enough fast travel points. This is the main problem with this game. I hope things get better because once a few of these issues are fixed this could be one of the best games ever.

												So add my review onto the pile of negatives. I see most of the positive reviews seem to be in direct response to the negative reviews and the which weigh in heavily on the Buggyness of the game in its released state. And most of those positive reviews are basing their positivity on the assumption that all bugs present will be fixed. I can say for sure that this is usually not the case, especially for a game released in full. They already have peoples money, they cashed in on the product. so even if they did want to polish it. They have little tangiable return guarantee to do so. Everyone should review a game (especially a full release) in its current state, not for what is planned or what could possibly be fixed later, because those are NEVER guarantees.This is my first hunting game, I played a couple hours of thehunter: classic as soon as I got to the microtransaction part (I like to play games, not money syphoning tubes). The first 6 hours of playing this game was fantastic. I completely forgot I was in my room on a computer. 100% immersion. Then, I found a bear. Bears are completely unfunctional. its as if they put the bear model, its sounds and 2 animations into the game a week before release. Half of the pause menu doesnt work with keyboard controls or any of the button prompts displayed on the bottom of the menu, This is something you fix in the first few weeks of development. I returned today into my game to do more hunting and found that none of the tracking indicators were workint, not even the direction cone when you identify a track. I had messed around with the tracking settings in my previous play session but that was to turn them back on. Sure enough, they were all on. I switched them of and on and this changed nothing, I restart my computer and this changed nothing. so one of the core mechanics of the gameplay is now bugged and my next step is to validate my game files which I will update when I do. This game is beautiful and runs well on my computer (gtx 1080 I7 6700)For those who want a good disconnect from life and a trip through the wilderness, $30 is quite modest. But expect to encounter sub alpha levels of bug fodder. And for a dev team who has a history in this genre, Its a bit sad to see.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 19
												For the few hours I have played CotW I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hunting game and doesn't want to pay extra for Classic.For people new to the franchise, I would start with CotW. It is the cheaper alternative and delivers for its price range. While Classic may have more animals, gameplay and community features CotW is a more inclusive system. Not nessecarily easier as it comes with its own challenges but the learning curve is more user-friendly.For people returning from previous theHunter games I believe it would depend on what you want. In a way, CotW is closer to Primal than Classic. There are fewer animals, less trophy diversity and fewer game mechanics but the AI is more advanced and the species don't feel like the same system tacked onto multiple different models.As for bugs I have only experienced one major one that simply required a game restart. There are several smaller ones that are more annoyances than game breaking, which I am sure will be patched out in the following weeks.As for the things I don't like, coming from Classic was a bit of a shock and while I know some people would be upset for the change, EW was very upfront that CotW would not be what Classic is. It was sold as a game that would not compete with Classic and some people seem to have forgotten that, or never understood what that ment. After a few hours of playing I grew to enjoy what CotW offers at this moment in time, however, it does feel rather empty. Such large maps with so little diversity.Despite this, I do think this game is worth buying. Be it now, or in a few months. If you are worried about bugs and missing features I would wait but definitely come back every once in awhile to see how the game progresses.Good luck and happy hunting!

You can easily get immersed due to the great sounds,lighting,and overall graphicsThe gameplay itself is pretty straight forward, you have a quest or two you can do if you want but overall you're just hunting which is great.Multiplayer is a mess, if the animals are not teleporting everywhere or invulnerable, they are running into trees and rocks and getting stuck ruining the fun of hunting. Many times you cant even harvest the animals you've killed.There are many gamebreaking bugs at the moment which leave me dumbfounded. Some of these bugs that i encounter all the time are        - Rifle scopes not working if you also have used a bow        - Waypoints have either not worked at all or will show you two places at once on your UI/HUD (lots of times both of them aren't even the spots you picked), also you can't delete them so you have to reload to get rid of them        - Tracking is pretty broken in many ways (leading you the wrong way, sometimes in a circle)        - Hit reg is really janky since the new update (double lung shots sometimes give minor wounds? wtf)        - Multiplayer is a mess Overall i love the game but I will never tell anyone to buy it due to the state the game was released in (patches have made it worse so far)

content:
ry 19
												For the few hours I have played CotW I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hunting game and doesn't want to pay extra for Classic.For people new to the franchise, I would start with CotW. It is the cheaper alternative and delivers for its price range. While Classic may have more animals, gameplay and community features CotW is a more inclusive system. Not nessecarily easier as it comes with its own challenges but the learning curve is more user-friendly.For people returning from previous theHunter games I believe it would depend on what you want. In a way, CotW is closer to Primal than Classic. There are fewer animals, less trophy diversity and fewer game mechanics but the AI is more advanced and the species don't feel like the same system tacked onto multiple different models.As for bugs I have only experienced one major one that simply required a game restart. There are several smaller ones that are more annoyances than game breaking, which I am sure will be patched out in the following weeks.As for the things I don't like, coming from Classic was a bit of a shock and while I know some people would be upset for the change, EW was very upfront that CotW would not be what Classic is. It was sold as a game that would not compete with Classic and some people seem to have forgotten that, or never understood what that ment. After a few hours of playing I grew to enjoy what CotW offers at this moment in time, however, it does feel rather empty. Such large maps with so little diversity.Despite this, I do think this game is worth buying. Be it now, or in a few months. If you are worried about bugs and missing features I would wait but definitely come back every once in awhile to see how the game progresses.Good luck and happy hunting!

												This review is written on 4.5 hours of playtime:To start, I love this game. Everyone's biggest issue with theHunter classic was that you had to pay (real money) for weapons and items. In CotW, you earn money to buy them by completing missions and harvesting animals. I love using the camera to take photos of an absolutely stunning visual experience.However, there are a lot of bugs, almost too many to mention and probably some that have not even been noticed yet. This is not acceptable for a full release game, if there is such a term anymore. It's 2017, developers dish out patches left and right to make thier games better, and I have a hard time believing Expansive Worlds will just up and give up on this game that they have been so passionate about.Verdict: If you want a hunting game, and hate microtransactions, this is the game for you. Otherwise, stick to the 'free' theHunter : Classic version for now. P.S. EW has voiced that both versions of theHunter will be living on, and that they are to go hand-in-hand.-Review will be tweaked as play time and patches go on-

content:
ry 16
												Really good game WITHOUT micro transaction or PAY to hunt everything.ALSO there are as far as i notised no serious bugs or problems, and the game do not feel unfinished or like a Beta like many "unserious reviews claim".I think that many of the reviews sound kind of fake and are negative on purpose.( im so glad they desided to release "the hunter" game with one payment only, since the pay for this and that scared med away from the previous title "the hunter".ANyway im not expert in the past game the hunter, and i only played the new "call of the wild" for 2 houres.But so far i enjoy it and the changes.The game world is beautifull and there are many cool features such as the plants moving when a small animal sneak arround.The sound is really amazing and create a good atmosphere and will make you feel releaxed.THe game have a career/skill/perk system wich will allow you to upgrade different things over time such as tracking animals and shooting ect.I think this is nice, since you start as a rookie hunter and become better and better.I am not aware if you can start as a "pro" hunter with all perks and all guns as a kind of free world go hunting kind of thing, but the career thing i like so for me no issue.When it come to animals you can hunt there are like 8-10 big animals such as "black bear, red tail, mose, fox, wild boar and other animals. And you dont have to pay to hunt them :-)Everytime you hunt down an animal you get awarded xp and money.The ingame money you earn can be used to buy new weapons, bullets and sometimes you even come across small buildings you can buy and use for hunting.The tracking of animals is like in the hunter, but i think it is a little more easy to see the tracks now.I think you can be hardcore and adjust the kind of help you like and how visual things will be.You can either go hunting on your own or with friends, and you also get  missions you can do, example hunt an animal and make a photo of it ( press p ).It effect the game how much you hunt in an area, and you can view this on your map as a purple colour, so try to not shoot everything you see, and do some different hunts all over the map.So far the only bug i found during 2 hour gameplay is that i fall down a mountain, and 5 minutes later I could not use any of my gear. But other than that, no big bugs that i notised.It run very good and smooth though the game world is huge and very detailed.Can i recommend this game.. YES i think it is really good, and I hope that they release some cheap dlc's in the future so people who like more animals or gear can buy example an weapon pack or animal pack.Ps. if you buy and do not like the game, then you can ask for a refund if you use the steam support system and play less than 2 houres.. So what do you have  to loose by giving it a try ;-)

content:
23
This game is a Hunter Simulator set in european deciduous forests, made by Expansive Worlds, a quite experienced hunter-sim developer underpined by Avalanche Studios and their really astonishing APEX Engine. Multiplayer included.  Aspect Annotation   Graphics, Atmosphere and Scenery:
☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺OO 
 The new APEX engine is definetely meritorious, it offers some great visual feedback for the player: Wind Simulation, Falling Leaves, Curving Grass and Decent Texture&Draw Distance. Eveverything in the games looks real enough for the player to relish it.   Gameplay:
☺☺☺☺☺☺OOOO It's kinda meh. The whole gameplay spins around following the trails of animals and then shooting them dead with deficient variativity. It's a notably protracted and tedious process, especially in late game. The Character is also really flaccid, and there are no vehicles in this game, and that convicts the player to spend half of his time walking from point A to point B on a really big map with the lack of fast travel spots. Multiplayer mode makes it much pleasant and fun though, but it still won't last for long.   Stability and Online:
☺☺☺☺☺OOOOO It's really poor. There are lots of gamebreaking bugs and gliches from disappearing corpses to critical error crashes. Same applies to the multiplayer, where crashes and disconnects are a comming thing  Overall: 7.1/10 While TheHunter:CotW ensures some fascinating immersion and visual fidelity, the amount of systematic problems and a considerably wearisome gameplay mechanics might dramatically spoil the impression of the game

content:
26
												Ok not going to rehash all the other great reviews out there already but as of this time I have 82 hours in it and i havent even made it to the second reserve . I dont know how some of you justify bang for the buck but with that much game play in half the game its pretty hard to ♥♥♥♥♥ even with the glitches which are certainly better than when released and being worked on all the time. If you like hunting games bingo its a winner if you like walking simulators also spot on. The rare few who actually like both its about as good as it gets in that sense ,plus a level grind aspect that keeps me playing with a goal to achieve . The glitches mentioned before while annoying are not game breaking the disappearing tracks issue is the hardest to deal with but also getting better (my suggestion is to be dam sure before you let that arrow or bullet fly). I like many others have literaly spent hours tracking a less that stellar shot to make sure i keep my consecutive harvest bonus going and it just seems wrong even in the game world to just take pot shots at everything then let them die slowly out in the brush to rot. I find if i just pick an undiscovered spot on the map and walk ( not run sometimes even in stealth which seems agonozingly slow) there I will several chances to track seomthing or even straight out walk up on a clean shot situation.I dont find the hunting blinds all that helpful but they do work you just have to use the calls but it seems boring when there is plenty to hunt walking around. Running is only a means to get from point a to b not a method to travel and expect to hun. The wildlife will hear you before you even get a warning call from them and its like your on a deserted planet. If your a twitch pvp gotta shoot a hundered rounds an hour player keep walking this isnt your game. There is however plenty of beautiful scenery and simply walking to open up map areas is enjoyable if you have a 5.1 or better headset or surround system crank it up and head into the woods listen for warning and mating calls and stealth towards them its very cool. Keep in mind which way your scent is going as it will tip them off before anything else does many times. I love the direction this game is going and cant wait to visit the other reserve looking forward to some new reserve dlcs maybe a few more things to hunt would rock but still pretty darn good now. I would like the option to start a second data or more so as i go to a new reserve i can start from scratch while still having the option to bring my developed character to look for bigger game as well . I love the level asect of it for me i like to have a goal to work towards there is a good mix of xp grind and  money grind here to keep you motiviated. They cant give it all to you for free at the start or you'd get bored quickly. I do feel like having to start over from scratch on the consecutive harvest thing is a bit of a pain but not horrible. I mostly find it makes it impossible to jump in and play for short bursts because so much of the game requires you to get gold kills and that is ony going to happen if you have 100% modifier on consecutive harvest as well as quick kill and it needs to be basically mythical grade animal.Graphics are really nice sometimes i just climb a mountain to see the view from up there some of the waters edge shots you get as well looking out over a tranquil mountiain lake or river is beautiful. Dont judge it by all the negative reviews while the points are valid a lot of times, many have been addressed and i have found none game breaking aggravating at times yes but not gamebreaking. I have only had one or two animals that i got any sort of decent shot into that didnt result in a successful harvest with diligent tracking and patience.Almost forgot dont forget to try the bow I started this game thinking good lord I'll never get close enough to anything to kill it with a bow but you will and its a real sense of accomplishment when you take down a mythical level red deer lets say with your bow very cool. I hunt almost exclusively with it now but still break out the 270 as well ,sometimes you just want to make sure especially if your on a mission and have 100% harvest bonus and dont want to risk it.There it is all i can think of hope it helps i enjoyed this game enough that i didnt even mind buying it full price 30 bucks is not outrageous . I looked at the classic version and I would never enjoy it as much as this one even with the larger number of things to hunt micro transaction games just leave me with a bad vibe and the days of monthy subscription games are pretty much done. Thnx hopefully this isnt too gramaticaly borked a nice spell checker gramar checker would be handy here lol.

content:

												I would like to start of by mentioning that this game looks beautiful, the sounds and feeling from the elements while going around tracking down game is something I have not seen in another game atleast not at this caliber. I'd love to give a really positive review, but sadly there are too many gamebreakers at the moment to try getting strangers of me to buy this game, unless you don't mind overlooking them.The first bug I encountered was the animals getting stuck between bushes and rocks, this one I noticed on my third kill of the game as a poor deer was running and running between a rock and a tree. After my current hours in the game I have seen this tens of times allready, but I wouldent call it gamebreaking, but it's a minus.In real hunting you rarly go for multiple shots towards diffrent games, but if you do in this game it seems like the tracking gets thrown of abit. Vital/flesh wounds on 'non' rare game not showing up & neither are tracks. A couple of times all tracks just disappeared all together and the only way I found to fix it was to reset the game, wich is a blunder when you are far of a outpost hunting(as in you only spawn in around the nearest outpost).The mission system is a good adition, but some of the missions are abit random to complete and some are better of leaving undone til you can afford and/or able to buy better equipment(ex. pictures of several animals of same race in a set zone). Some quests seems bugged, as they would not complete even if conditions are met(ex. killing deer at night).What I do like is how much of a grind it is to max your hunting skills and perks you can pick up.The real gamebreaker for me is the random and unexpected crashes, screen freezes with looping sound. Giving it a quick search just shows how many are affected by this and there has not been a single respons from the game developers about this yet. They seem to happen more and more depending on how much of a map you have explored, as I can play one of the zones without a crash for longer then the more explored zone(but what do I know). So for me when I am in the zone, focused to bring down game, take a shot and trying to track down the giant moose to see how big it actually was. And for it all to be a waste of time by a frozen screen and looping sound, meh I got better things to do then playing a non-finished game.My review of this game were from the last week intil today, 10/3-17. I might change my mind about this if there is a game fixing patch coming, but I would advice to wait to pick this up to see if they manage to change this visual pearl to a hour sandbox.

												This game has potential, but typical of an Expensive Worlds release, it's chock full of bugs. The hit detection is just awful.  Shots that would be kill shots in real life are flesh wounds in this game.  What is really frustrating is the misleading "free gun and gillie suit" promotion.  If you have both theHunter classic and theHunter: Call of the Wild, you don't get the gun and gillie suit for free, you get the opportunity to buy them.  Yes, you buy them with in-game money, but it takes a long time to earn enough to buy them.  As of right now, I can't recommend this game, and I wish I wouldn't have bought it.  Maybe after a few patches, and some more patches to kill the bugs they introduce with those patches, it will be playable, but right now, I'd stay away.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 16
												theHunter: Call of the Wild,I'd give her 5 stars. Not entirely sure what all the hate and absolute disgust is all about, I have found nothing but greatness in the product.Yes, sure there are a few issues here and there, but nothing that patches won't be able to iron out. Right, just a brief reason why I rate COTW so highly with a pro's and con's list below.Call of the Wild has some of the most beautiful, calming and pleasuring forests, plains, rivers and mountains to explore, the ambiance the game creates in that regard is utter beauty.The animals themselves are really great to look at and stalk. Sure the Buck do not have the hugest varity of Antlers out there, but i am curious to see what the future holds in that regard. Thus far each hunt has been majestic in its own way. Each hunt has brought about its own challenges and adventure with it. From hunting Red Fox to Various types of Deers, some animals are in a herd which force me to choose wisely and play my tactics carefully if i wish to leave with the best scoring animal, those that travel alone are often very sneaky and sometimes downright genius, though with enough patience and technique, the hunt will reward you with the sight of beauty and the pleasure of the one shot kill. (To which I have noticed a lot of people complaining about 3 shots to bring down a buck.... I have yet to have such an issue. 12 shots fired. 12 hits, 12 kills.Anyhow onto the Pro's and Con's list.Con's:1) Small game and Big game create the same noise while passing through foilage/bushes which is hugely missleading or should i say somewhat confusing, I have caught myself doing 360s with the rifle aimed, looking for that deer that made that racket while passing through the bushes, to see only later that it was merely a rabbit. Very odd for a Rabbit to make such a loud crash through the bushes.2) A couple of glitches while in Map mode, You have to constantly zoom in and out to see the borders of various places on the map, which isnt very helpful while trying to complete missions, but by no means a game breaker.3) A few animals are still getting glitched/stuck on various rocks and or tree trunks, Thus far has only happend twice out of the 12 animals i have had the opportunity of taking down.That is really it thus far.Pros:1) The beautifully designed Forests, Plains, Rivers, Mountains etc etc are a sight for sore eyes. I have no issues getting lost in them and just strolling through watching gazing Buck stroll through the wild. 2) The ambiance in the wild is fantastic, it really makes you feel as if you are in the wild, from the birds chirping, to the foxes howling (Squeeking?) to the birds flying out of the bushes while you hastly run past. The wind that blows over the plains and the odd time Thunder strikes the silent evening sky behind you. Its brilliantly done.3) The Animals are very goodlooking, From the Rabbit through to the various Deers (I have yet to find myself a Bear or any other larger Game, thus i have to hold that comment). They act very well, and I have yet to have issues with them spooking just to stop a few meters later. When they spook, my god do they run, and stop very very far away. Have had some fantastic 2 hour marches following those Tracks.4) The whole feeling to the game is great, It is not elite hardcore, but is by no means like a Call of Duty Hunter. I see tons of complaints that the game is far too arcade like, but I cannot seem to grasp what that means. The hunts are by no means easy, You can spend a very long time tracking down your prey, very easily spook him off and very easily miss your shot. (Unless ofcourse you are using your rifle like its a machine gun and shooting every animal in sight... well then you have no idea what hunting is about).Thats about it for now, I will ofcourse update the review at a later stage.All in all,I will be spending tons of hours on this beaut of a game.
